questions.prompt: Which type of system uses differential equations for modeling?
questions.explanation: Continuous-time systems are modeled by differential equations because they deal with continuous signals x(t) where derivatives dx/dt are defined. Discrete-time systems use difference equations instead.

questions.prompt: A bank account balance updated monthly is best modeled as:
questions.explanation: A bank balance is updated at discrete time intervals (monthly), making it a discrete-time system. The balance y[n] depends on previous balance y[n-1] plus interest and deposits, forming a difference equation.

questions.prompt: For the RLC circuit equation LC(d²v/dt²) + RC(dv/dt) + v = x(t), what is the system order?
questions.explanation: The order of a differential equation (and thus the system) is determined by the highest derivative. Here d²v/dt² is the highest, making it a second-order system.

questions.prompt: Which equation represents a discrete-time system?
questions.explanation: The equation y[n] = 0.5y[n-1] + x[n] uses discrete indices [n] and [n-1], characteristic of difference equations for discrete-time systems. All other options use continuous-time notation.
An ADC samples a continuous-time signal at discrete intervals and quantizes the values, converting continuous analog signals into discrete-time digital signals.

questions.prompt: The time constant τ of a first-order system RC is:
questions.explanation: For an RC circuit, the time constant τ = RC determines how quickly the system responds. After time t = τ, the response reaches about 63.2% of its final value.

questions.prompt: A difference equation y[n] - y[n-1] = x[n] represents which operation?
questions.explanation: The backward difference y[n] - y[n-1] is the discrete-time analog of differentiation. It approximates dy/dt in continuous time and measures the rate of change.

questions.prompt: Which statement about system classification is TRUE?
options: Continuous-time systems cannot be implemented digitally
Discrete-time systems can approximate continuous-time behavior
Differential equations only apply to electrical systems
questions.correctAnswer: Discrete-time systems can approximate continuous-time behavior
questions.explanation: With sufficiently high sampling rates, discrete-time systems can accurately approximate continuous-time behavior. This is the basis of digital signal processing and digital control systems.

questions.prompt: For the system y(t) = ∫x(τ)dτ, this represents:
questions.explanation: The integral operation accumulates the input signal over time, making this an integrator. The output is the 'running total' of the input, which is the opposite of differentiation.

questions.prompt: The discrete-time accumulator y[n] = Σx[k] for k from -∞ to n is the discrete equivalent of:
questions.explanation: The accumulator sums all past input values, which is the discrete-time equivalent of integration. Just as integration is the inverse of differentiation, accumulation is the inverse of differencing.
